title: Lavender Tallow Balm: I Tried Beef Fat on My Face So You Don't Have To Be Weirded Out
body:
Okay so. I bought beef fat for my face. I know. It sounds like something you’d find in a weird historical reenactment pamphlet, not on your bathroom shelf next to your toothpaste. My neighbor’s TV was blaring some cooking show through the wall when the package arrived and I just stared at it. A little jar of whipped tallow balm. Lavender scent. From some Etsy shop in France. I was fully prepared for it to be a greasy, smelly mess. My skin was just… angry. Winter hit and it was like my face decided to become a dry, flaky desert. The expensive stuff in the fancy glass bottles wasn’t cutting it. So I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I’d look like a glazed donut for a night. Anyway, here’s what actually happened with this grass-fed beef tallow balm.

## How I Even Got Here (It's a Weird Story)

It started with my elbows. Seriously. They were so dry they looked like cracked pottery. I was complaining about it to my mom on the phone and she was like, “your grandmother used to keep a tin of something in the cold room for her hands.” And I was half-listening, scrolling through my phone, and this Etsy ad pops up. Whipped tallow balm. For skin. The algorithm is creepy. But the pictures looked… normal? Like nice cream. Not like a lump of fat. The description said it was made from grass-fed beef suet, whipped up in France, and it was this lavender one for calming. For sleep. My brain was just tired. I clicked buy. It was a Tuesday, I think. Maybe Wednesday. The whole thing felt impulsive and vaguely ridiculous.

So it shows up. The jar is cute, I’ll give it that. Not what I expected. I unscrewed the lid expecting… I don’t know, a barnyard smell? It didn’t smell like that. It smelled like lavender. But not like a candle. More like the actual plant, if you crushed it in your hand. A little earthy maybe. Or herbal. I don’t have a good nose for this stuff. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter, but when you scoop some it just melts. Like, immediately. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. It went on kind of thick but then it was just… gone. No grease. My skin just drank it. That was the first “huh” moment.

## Why Beef Tallow for Skin Isn't Actually Crazy

Wait, where was I going with this. Right. So I’m putting beef fat on my hand and it’s not gross. I had to look this up because my brain needed a reason. The science-y bit, but the simple version. Our skin makes oil, right? Sebum. It’s a mix of fats. Tallow from grass-fed cows is apparently really close to that mix. Like, structurally similar. So the idea is your skin recognizes it. It’s not some alien, lab-made silicone—it’s a fat your skin knows how to use. It absorbs. It doesn’t just sit on top and clog everything up. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it’s already trying to make. That made a weird kind of sense to me. Grandma wisdom meeting biochemistry. She wasn’t just rubbing random fat on her hands; she was using what worked for centuries before petroleum jelly was a thing. Before lotions with 25 unpronounceable ingredients. It’s just… fat. Good, clean fat from an animal that ate grass. That’s the whole tallow skincare benefits thing, I guess. It’s simple. Annoyingly simple.

I started using it that night. Just on my elbows and my knuckles, which were also a disaster. The next morning they were… better. Not perfect. But softer. Less like they’d snag on my sweater. No residue. So I got brave. I used it on my face. After I washed it, before bed. I was watching some terrible movie, half-paying attention, just massaging this little bit of balm in. The lavender smell was actually really nice. Not perfumey. Just calm. It didn’t make me smell like a roast, I promise. My face felt… protected. Not suffocated. I fell asleep on the couch and woke up at like 3 AM with the TV still on. My face didn’t feel tight. That was new.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does (For Me)

So a few weeks in. My routine is chaos but this stuck. I keep the jar on my nightstand. The lavender one is supposed to be calming, for anxiety relief or whatever. I don’t know about all that. But the ritual of it? Putting it on is slow. You have to scoop it, let it melt in your fingers, then press it in. You can’t rush it. It forces you to stop for a second. That part is relaxing. My mind goes quiet for a minute. That’s probably the real sleep-promoting thing. Not the scent, but the act of just taking a damn minute for yourself.

As for my skin? It’s just… quiet now. It’s not a miracle. I didn’t turn into a dewy newborn. But the winter rage is gone. No more flakes around my nose. No more sandpaper cheeks. When I get out of the shower, my skin doesn’t feel like it’s screaming for moisture anymore. It just feels like skin. My elbows are genuinely smooth. I used it on a cut on my hand once—just a little paper cut—and it healed up faster. I read that tallow has vitamins A, D, E, K… all that good stuff that helps skin repair itself. Seems legit. I got one for my mom too, for her eczema on her hands. She texted me last week: “What is in this witchcraft cream?” She’s on board.

## Would I Buy This Beef Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. The first one lasted forever, you need so little. I got mine from this little Etsy shop, the one that makes it in France. It feels like someone’s actually making it, not a factory. That matters to me. The ingredients list is short. Grass-fed beef tallow, some lavender oil, that’s basically it. I like knowing what I’m putting on my face. It’s just… food for your skin. No weird chemicals, no fillers. Just simple, natural ingredients.

It’s not for everyone. If you’re vegan, obviously no. If you want something that smells like a tropical vacation, this isn’t it. It smells like a herb garden at dusk. Timeless, I guess. Herbal. It’s a night cream for me. A winter savior. A thing that just works when my skin decides to be difficult.

Anyway. My phone is at 12%. I should plug it in. If your skin is feeling rough, or dry, or just pissed off at the weather, maybe give tallow a shot. It sounds weirder than it is. Honestly.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it can be. Sounds wild, but because it’s so similar to our skin’s own oils, it absorbs really well. It doesn’t just sit there and clog pores. It’s like giving your skin something it actually knows how to use. My face seems to think so, anyway.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me, and I can get clogged pores easy. It absorbs. It’s not like putting cooking grease on. The whipped texture is light, it melts right in. If you use a tiny amount, you’re golden. A little goes a long, long way.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not like air freshener. It’s earthy and herbal, a little green. It’s calming. It doesn’t stick around all night, it’s just a nice scent while you’re putting it on. It’s subtle. I like it.

So yeah. If you're curious, might be worth checking out. My skin's happy. I'm happy. That's all I wanted.
